Introduction to CSS

Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in a markup language like HTML.CSS is a cornerstone technology of the World Wide Web, alongside HTML and JavaScript

  • CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets
  • CSS describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media
  • CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once
  • External stylesheets are stored in CSS files
  • CSS is not a programming language.

Border

The CSS border properties allow you to specify the style, width, and color of an element's border.

To specify the border individually, you can use this:

  • border-top
  • border-right
  • border-bottom
  • border-left

               .container {
                    border: 3px solid #000;
                }

Color

There's a lot of ways to add colors in our CSS. It can be

  • Predefined color (color names)
  • RGB (red, green, blue)
  • HEX (hexadecimal value)
  • HSL (hue ,saturation, lightness)
  • RGBA (red, green, blue, alpha)
  • HSLA (hue, saturation, lightness, alpha)

            nav {
              background-color: midnightblue; 
              color: #ffffff; 
            }

CSS Combinators

A combinator is something that explains the relationship between the selectors.

A CSS selector can contain more than one simple selector. Between the simple selectors, we can include a combinator.

There are four different combinators in CSS:

  • descendant selector (space)
  • child selector (>)
  • adjacent sibling selector (+)
  • general sibling selector (~)

            div > p {
              background-color: yellow;
            }

CSS Units

CSS has several different units for expressing a length.

Many CSS properties take "length" values, such as width, margin, padding, font-size, etc.

Length is a number followed by a length unit, such as 10px, 2em, etc.

  • Absolute Length - are fixed and a length expressed in any of these will appear as exactly that size.
  • Relative Length - specify a length relative to another length property. Relative length units scales better between different rendering mediums.

            p {
              font-size: 25px;
              line-height: 50px;
            }

Fonts

The CSS font properties define the font family, boldness, size, and the style of a text.

In CSS there are five generic font families:

  • Serif - fonts have a small stroke at the edges of each letter. They create a sense of formality and elegance.
  • Sans-serif - fonts have clean lines (no small strokes attached). They create a modern and minimalistic look.
  • Monospace - fonts here all the letters have the same fixed width. They create a mechanical look.
  • Cursive - fonts imitate human handwriting.
  • Fantasy - fonts are decorative/playful fonts.

            body {
              font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
            }

This will create a Arial font to all elements inside the body element,Helvetica, is the fallback font incase the Arial is not supported by user the web browser. The sans-serif is the family where the font belongs.

Margin

The CSS margin properties are used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

To specify the margin individually, you can use this:

  • margin-top
  • margin-right
  • margin-bottom
  • margin-left

            .container {
              margin: 10px 20px;
            }

This will create a 10px margin from top and bottom. 20px in right and left top, right,bottom,left is the chronological order of margin

Opacity

The opacity property specifies the opacity/transparency of an element.

  • The opacity property is often used together with the :hover selector to change the opacity on mouse-over:
  • The opacity property can take a value from 0.0 - 1.0.

            img {
              opacity: 0.5;
            }

Overflow

The overflow property specifies whether to clip the content or to add scrollbars when the content of an element is too big to fit in the specified area.

The overflow property has the following values:

  • visible - Default. The overflow is not clipped. The content renders outside the element's box.
  • hidden - The overflow is clipped, and the rest of the content will be invisible
  • scroll - The overflow is clipped, and a scrollbar is added to see the rest of the content
  • auto - Similar to scroll, but it adds scrollbars only when necessary

            .container {
              overflow: hidden;
            }

Padding

The CSS padding properties are used to generate space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.

To specify the padding individually, you can use this:

  • padding-top
  • padding-right
  • padding-bottom
  • padding-left

            .container {
              padding: 20px;
            }

This will create a padding of 20px in top, right, bottom and left

Position

The position property specifies the type of positioning method used for an element.

There are five different position values:

  • static
  • relative
  • fixed
  • absolute
  • sticky

            .container {
              position: relative;
            }

Pseudo-Classes

A pseudo-class is used to define a special state of an element.

For example, it can be used to:

  • Style an element when a user mouses over it
  • Style visited and unvisited links differently
  • Style an element when it gets focus

            selector:pseudo-class {
              property: value;
            }

Pseudo-Elements

A CSS pseudo-element is used to style specified parts of an element.

For example, it can be used to:

  • Style the first letter, or line, of an element
  • Insert content before, or after, the content of an element

            selector::pseudo-element {
              property: value;
            }
